And at that point, should these nooses still be ignored?

You know, very often, I pass the plaza here where the Nazis burned the books from the Humboldt University, and there's a plaque there that says, you know, when a nation burns its books, next it burns its people.
And so therefore, I see the noose as, yes, it's a terrorist threat, a terroristic threat.
And also, it's a real escalation.
And I'd like to know how your speaker would react to - if this does go a step further, do we then still ignore these symbols?
John McWhorter, I think that's to you.
Well, I can say that when you're looking at things like this, you have to be open to contradictions to the way you look at things.
And I'm quite sure that if we saw a black man hanging from a tree next week, then I would change my tune on this.
You have to be open to doing it.
I do it all the time.
However, I think that the current situation in the United States is such that that is vanishingly unlikely and I would put myself on the line and say that here in this national forum.

And so I'm responding to it in a different interpretation of the nooses, which is equally plausible to the one that supposes that we're in for a new spade of lynchings, which is that people are making a really nasty gesture because they see that it gets a response.

The Diversity Web site with the map is very interesting and very useful in its way, but each new noose that you see in each new state says to me that once again, this has become something which has proliferated so much that what we need to do is take this sting away from the power of it to intimidate by not being frightened because that's one way of making these things stop.
Hmm.
Why do you think the map is interesting, John McWhorter?
Well, because this is an important point.
Often people, especially people in my position, say, well, racism still exists, and then they move on.
And I think it is important to chart the fact that racism really does still exist.
There are white people out there, and not just a few, who have severe biases against black people.
The playing field is not level.
And I think there need to be graphic indications if that's true so that we can know what obstacles people do face, what the Americans psychology still is.
That's not useless.

However, I maintain that when it comes to these nooses, and the media response to them or the legal response, I think the solution to getting rid of that symbol or at least, lessening it is not to make it big deal every time one of them comes up.
It seems counterproductive to me.
Mm-hmm.
Luke Visconti, what do you think?

Well, I think that we have to look at the reality in our country that most white people think that the problem has pretty much gone away, yet, black households have one-tenth the wealth of white households.
And if you look at schools that underserve their students, the majority of them are in black towns like we're in, in Newark, where my office is.
And I think that the noose is a symbol.
Noose is a sign that things aren't as good as a lot - as the majority seemed to think they are.

And by illustrating them and making them nationally known instead of just a local sign of terror, I think you do justice to the, you know, the fact or awareness that things are not as good as we all seem to think they are.
And it is disturbing for all people to understand that they aren't as good as people seem to think they are.
And, Luke Visconti, when you say terror, well, terrorism is a crime.
Should these nooses be criminalized as the New York State Legislature is considering doing?
Yes.
I think they should be just as spray painting a swastika on a Jewish person's home is a crime.
I think that any sort of hate speech like this, which has a violent intent behind it, should be a crime.
Okay.
Benjamin, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
Okay.
Thank you.

Bye-bye.

This is from Stan(ph) on e-mail.
There is no single or simple answer to the question you posed.
As a black man in America, I know I'll often have to make the split-second determination of how to respond to racism.
Is the act malicious or just ignorant?
If malicious, what's the potential danger I want to confront by responding?
If ignorant, what's the likelihood that an ignorant person is prepared to learn the error of his or her ways?
Understand that a person of color in America expend a tremendous amount of mental capacity on this calculus every day.
John McWhorter, would you agree with that?

Well, I don't know if it's an everyday occurrence and I'm viscerally uncomfortable with the idea that to be black is to be eternally torn and agonized in 2007, maybe that's just me, I suspect it isn't.
But, yes, these are things which often have a case by case aspect to them, which is what I would have said about the nooses, when at least in terms of public awareness.
It wasn't something that was so common.
However, when it gets to the point that it's something that pops up on the Web every three days, I think that we might have to change our tactics.

And to make that kind of careful evaluation about everyone of these cases is, once again, to give power to these extremely minor and small-minded people, instead of being a self-satisfied, strong human being who has a life.
I also should point out that in your piece, you said, there are moments when protest is appropriate and you've cited the Don Imus case.
Yup.
Also, the protest in Jena itself was certainly - I wasn't there, but it seemed to have had the aspect of being much more about what people believed was a miscarriage of justice...
Oh, yeah...
...rather than the nooses itself.
Yeah, yeah.
My point here is not: Don't protest.
This is not a kind of black bourgeoisie discomfort with making noise or anything like that.
There is injustice.
I think that Reed Walters down in Jena is an absolutely repulsive figure.
I wrote an op-ed that apparently was kind of around a little less about that.
And so, I was very much in favor of, for example, Trent Lott being demoted after what he said about Strom Thurmond.
I understand all of that.
But there are times when the idea that the black thing to do is to put your fist in the air and make noise is less effective than other times.
And so it's in this particular case, you know, I'm known as the black conservative.
Notice that I'm not really saying anything all that's conservative; my interest is in getting rid of these nooses.
We walk on by them to get rid of them, not because we don't know what they mean.
I'm very grateful to you, John McWhorter, well, first of all, because I've listened to you for a while in African-American Roundtable and such.
I'm a white woman in Northern California and I think it's entirely possible that our responses to these should be different if we're black or if we're white.

Because the studies are showing, psychologically, that when you remind people who are a minority, whether they're young women or African-Americans or whatever, before taking a test that they are a minority, they score less.
And so reinforcing this idea of difference doesn't necessarily work to our common goal of overcoming racism.

But on the other hand, as a white person who grew up in Oregon and much later in life learned that my sheriff had been telling black people to leave town before sunrise, I would had no idea that that was going on if I hadn't learned that.
And there is something I think is very effective about white people knowing that these numbers of nooses are showing up places.
I happen to do a little bit of diversity work in the area of white privilege.
And so I have seen the Web site the DiversityInc.
has with the nooses and it's shocking.

Hmm.

So I think it's good education for everybody to understand that nature of the problem that we're all facing.

Here's an e-mail from Edward(ph) in Nashville, Tennessee.
No one has the right to tell me, much as legislate, what my symbols should stand for.
Charge me with trespassing if I hang the noose on someone else's property, but don't take away my right to assign meanings to my own symbols.
John McWhorter, I don't think we've heard from you on this point.
Is the New York State Legislature correct if it votes to make this a felony?
Well, I would say that answer to that would have to be no, because I genuinely believe that in a way, it is demeaning to black people.
I understand DiversityInc.'s desire to show that racism still exists.
But I guess it's a matter of priorities.
I'm more interested in helping black people to make the best of themselves who've been left behind.
So prisoner reentry efforts are important.
Health care efforts are important.
All sorts of things that I try to pay close attention to - job training efforts for people who've been left behind.
These are the things that are important.

Showing that racism still exists, that there are white people who don't like black people and that the playing field isn't perfectly level, is something that I consider a lesser priority because it's unclear to me that there could exist in human society where there was no racism whatsoever, or where a playing field was perfectly level.
So I'm interested in trying to help people and trying to support legislation that would do that.

The issue of demonstrating that the country is imperfect in terms of how people feel of black - about black people, has always struck me as a second-level issue because I'm not sure we can truly do as much about those things as we would like.
So hurray for the site, but personally, I'm more interested in activist work that helps people to do their best despite the obstacles.
And I think that that can happen and it is happening.
John McWhorter...
I'd like to respond to that.

You bet.
We give away two percent of our gross income to support scholarships for higher education.

I think that you can do good work and illustrate what's going wrong with the country in an effort to improve the situation.

So I don't think - I don't appreciate the kind of belittling of the - of my Web site or the intent behind it because I actually do give away hundreds of thousands of dollars to fund scholarships at schools.
